articles.title: Reeves to guarantee paid work for young people unemployed for 18 months
articles.summary: The chancellor will commit to "the abolition of long-term youth unemployment" in her speech at Labour conference.
articles.content:
Reeves to guarantee paid work for young people unemployed for 18 months

6 hours ago Share Save Becky Morton Political reporter Share Save

PA Media

Young people who have been out of a job or education for 18 months will be offered a guaranteed paid work placement, Rachel Reeves is set to announce. Those who do not to take up the offer could face being stripped of their benefits. In her speech to Labour's annual conference in Liverpool, the chancellor will promise "nothing less than the abolition of long-term youth unemployment". Reeves is also expected to make the case for a society founded on "contribution", where "hard work is matched by fair reward". It comes ahead of November's Budget, with the chancellor under pressure to balance the public finances, while also boosting economic growth.

The scheme builds on a "youth guarantee", announced last November, which promised every 18 to 21-year-old in England access to an apprenticeship, training, education opportunities or help to find a job. Under the new initiative, every young person who has been on Universal Credit for 18 months without "earning or learning" will be offered a guaranteed paid work placement. Those who refuse to take up the offer without a reasonable excuse will face sanctions such as losing their benefits. The aim of the placements would be to help people build up the skills to get a full-time job. An estimated one-in-eight 16-24-year-olds are not currently in education, employment or training - around 948,000 people - according to the latest figures. The numbers hit an 11-year high of 987,000 at the end of last year.

The new scheme will build on existing employment support and work placements delivered by the Department for Work and Pensions. It will work with private companies, with the government anticipating businesses would cover at least some of the wages for job placements. The government has not given a figure for the cost of the scheme but it will be funded from existing budgets set out in the spending review earlier this year. Full details will be set out in November's Budget, when the chancellor sets out the government's tax and spending plans. Reeves is facing a difficult Budget, with economists warning tax rises or spending cuts will be needed for the chancellor to meet her self-imposed borrowing rules. In her conference speech, the chancellor is expected to say: "I will never be satisfied while too many people's potential is wasted, frozen out of employment, education, or training. There's no defending it. "It's bad for business, bad for taxpayers, bad for our economy, and it scars people's prospects throughout their lives." She will add: "Just as the last Labour government, with its new deal for young people, abolished long-term youth unemployment I can commit this government to nothing less than the abolition of long-term youth unemployment." The announcement was welcomed by the Federation of Small Businesses as "hugely important". The group's policy chair, Tina McKenzie, said: "Reprioritising spending from employment programmes which aren't working to this type of scheme is exactly the way to get much-needed bang for taxpayer cash." She added: "Key to getting the details right is making sure there is a backstop offer to those who are now over-25, particularly those with health challenges; that young people out of work for health reasons are not excluded through misguided double funding rules; and that small businesses are enabled to play a full role in the delivery of the scheme." However, there are questions over whether businesses facing pressures including increases in National Insurance Contributions and the National Minimum Wage would be able to take on large numbers of new workers. The number of job vacancies in the UK has been falling, hitting their lowest level since the pandemic earlier this year.

In her speech, Reeves will also set out her belief in a "Britain based on opportunity", where "ordinary kids can flourish, unhindered by their background". "I believe in a Britain founded on contribution - where we do our duty for each other, and where hard work is matched by fair reward," she is expected to say. It comes after the influential think tank Labour Together published a report last week arguing the government should put the idea of "contribution" - that if you pay in to the system, you should be able to see what you get out of it - at the heart of its agenda.

The chancellor will also pledge to fund a library in every primary school in England. Around one-in-seven state primary schools in England - roughly 1,700 - do not have a library, according to figures from the National Literacy Trust, rising to one-in-four for disadvantaged areas.

articles.personality_title: UK government to guarantee paid jobs for young people unemployed 18 months
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Many young people in the UK struggle to find jobs or education, with nearly one in eight aged 16 to 24 currently not working or studying. Long-term unemployment among youth has reached its highest level in over a decade.

**What happened** – Chancellor Rachel Reeves announced at the Labour Party conference a new plan to offer paid work placements to any young person unemployed or out of education for 18 months. Those who refuse the placements without good reason could lose their benefits. This builds on a previous youth guarantee program and involves partnerships with private companies who may help pay wages.

**Impact** – This plan aims to help nearly a million young people develop skills and get back into full-time work. It promises to reduce long-term youth unemployment, which harms individuals’ futures and the economy. The scheme also encourages fairness by linking hard work with rewards and hopes to involve small businesses.

**What's next step** – Full details will be revealed in the government’s November Budget, including funding and how the program will operate. The government will need to balance this support with financial rules and economic pressures.

**One-sentence takeaway** – The UK government is launching a new program to guarantee paid job placements for young people unemployed 18 months, aiming to reduce youth unemployment and help them build skills for the future.
articles.personality_title_fr: Le gouvernement britannique garantit des emplois rémunérés aux jeunes sans travail depuis 18 mois
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – De nombreux jeunes au Royaume-Uni ont du mal à trouver un emploi ou une formation, près d’un sur huit âgés de 16 à 24 ans n’étant ni en travail ni en étude. Le chômage de longue durée chez les jeunes est à son plus haut niveau depuis plus de dix ans.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – La chancelière Rachel Reeves a annoncé lors de la conférence du Parti travailliste un nouveau plan pour offrir des emplois rémunérés aux jeunes sans emploi ou formation depuis 18 mois. Ceux qui refuseraient sans raison valable pourraient perdre leurs allocations. Ce programme s’appuie sur une garantie jeunesse antérieure et prévoit une collaboration avec des entreprises privées qui pourraient aider à payer les salaires.

**Impact** – Ce plan vise à aider près d’un million de jeunes à acquérir des compétences et à retrouver un emploi à temps plein. Il promet de réduire le chômage de longue durée chez les jeunes, qui affecte leur avenir et l’économie. Le programme encourage également l’équité en associant travail et récompense, et espère impliquer les petites entreprises.

**Prochaine étape** – Les détails complets seront dévoilés dans le Budget de novembre, incluant le financement et le fonctionnement du programme. Le gouvernement devra équilibrer ce soutien avec ses règles financières et les pressions économiques.

**Une phrase clé** – Le gouvernement britannique lance un programme garantissant des emplois rémunérés aux jeunes sans travail depuis 18 mois, pour réduire le chômage des jeunes et les aider à développer leurs compétences.
articles.personality_title_es: El gobierno del Reino Unido garantiza empleos pagados para jóvenes desempleados 18 meses
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Muchos jóvenes en el Reino Unido tienen dificultades para encontrar trabajo o educación, con casi uno de cada ocho entre 16 y 24 años sin empleo ni estudios. El desempleo juvenil de larga duración está en su nivel más alto en más de una década.

**Qué pasó** – La ministra de Hacienda, Rachel Reeves, anunció en la conferencia del Partido Laborista un nuevo plan para ofrecer trabajos pagados a jóvenes desempleados o fuera de la educación por 18 meses. Quienes rechacen las ofertas sin una razón válida podrían perder sus beneficios. Este plan se basa en una garantía juvenil previa y trabajará con empresas privadas que podrían ayudar a pagar los salarios.

**Impacto** – El plan busca ayudar a casi un millón de jóvenes a desarrollar habilidades y regresar a empleos a tiempo completo. Promete reducir el desempleo juvenil de larga duración, que afecta el futuro de las personas y la economía. También promueve la justicia al vincular el trabajo duro con recompensas y espera contar con la participación de pequeñas empresas.

**Próximo paso** – Los detalles completos se presentarán en el Presupuesto de noviembre, incluyendo el financiamiento y la operación del programa. El gobierno tendrá que equilibrar este apoyo con sus reglas financieras y las presiones económicas.

**Una frase clave** – El gobierno del Reino Unido lanzará un programa que garantiza empleos pagados para jóvenes desempleados por 18 meses, con el objetivo de reducir el desempleo juvenil y ayudarlos a desarrollar habilidades para el futuro.
